author: Lexie Horvath
title: chevron-right
text: EAST BRAINERD, Tenn. ‚Äî [Tornadoes struck middle Tennessee earlier this month](https://newschannel9.com/news/local/2023-tennessee-tornadoes-deadly-lives-lost-fourth-clarksville-tornado-victim-dies-from-injuries-local-reports-say-montgomery-county-middle-tn), killing seven people and and injuring many others. Those tornadoes also damaged buildings and knocked out power for thousands of people. Those storms, as well as others in our area, have left residents looking for ways to stay safe. Thursday we spoke to someone who has experienced disaster first hand about what you can add to your home to protect yourself and your family. So that when severe weather strikes, you'll be prepared. Building a storm shelter came as a no-brainer for East Brainerd Resident Michael Herston. In 2020 his home was considered a ‚Äútotal devastation‚Äù from [ the Easter tornados.](https://newschannel9.com/news/local/severe-weather-causes-major-local-damage-late-sunday-night) "For me, it's not even an option. Whatever the costs, that's safety and security. That's first for us," says Herston. He brought in a whole team of structural engineers and designers to provide the safest and sturdiest structure for his family. ‚ÄúI mean, it's your life. It's your life or a few 1,000 bucks. I'm going to spend the money on saving a life," Herston says. But Chattanooga Realtor Dawn O'Neil says it's a costly addition. "With the housing market, the way we have it, it's just hard to justify putting another $10,000 into a storm shelter," says O'Neil. But it's not the only way. She says there are more convenient options that home builders are including other than a concrete shelter. "A lot of builders put doors underneath staircases, things like that. That is great for storage, but it's also great for a place to go if you don't have a basement," O'Neil says. Just a few weeks ago, tornadoes raged through Middle Tennessee, bringing storm shelters back to top of mind for homeowners in Chattanooga. ‚ÄúEspecially with the tornadoes that just happened and being so close in proximity, I think that's something that people are aware of," says O'Neil. But the building of storm shelters hits closer to home. ‚ÄúIn 2020 when the storms came to Holly Hills, I think that was something that people, when they were looking at homes, were interested in and it was kind of in the forefront of their mind," O'Neil says. Including homeowner Michael Herston. "Going forward, I'll never have a house again that doesn't have one," Herston says. Data from the National Weather Service shows that the average yearly tornado total since 1950 has been 19 per year. However, the average yearly total since 1995 is higher, reaching 32 tornadoes per year on average.

title: KTM in crisi, debiti miliardari e migliaia di posti di lavoro a rischio
text:
KTM in crisi, debiti miliardari e migliaia di posti di lavoro a rischio
Articolo Precedente
Articolo Successivo
La KTM, colosso europeo delle due ruote, ha recentemente presentato istanza di fallimento presso il tribunale di Ried im Innkreis, in Austria, a causa di un debito complessivo di 2,9 miliardi di euro. La crisi finanziaria dell'azienda, che ha accumulato passivit√† per 1,8 miliardi di euro, √® stata aggravata da un'eccedenza di oltre 130.000 moto, risultato di un evidente aumento dei costi e di un calo della domanda.
L'Associazione dei creditori alpini (AKV) ha stimato il debito totale delle tre entit√† coinvolte - KTM AG, KTM Components GmbH e KTM Forschungs und Entwicklungs GmbH - a 2,9 miliardi di euro. La situazione ha messo a rischio circa tremila posti di lavoro, gettando nello sconforto i dipendenti della Casa di Mattighofen.
La documentazione presentata da KTM AG al tribunale regionale di Ried im Innkreis ha rivelato l'entit√† delle passivit√†, mentre l'AKV ha fornito una stima complessiva del debito, evidenziando la gravit√† della situazione. La crisi ha colpito duramente l'azienda, che si √® trovata a fronteggiare un debito sbalorditivo e una domanda in calo, con conseguenze devastanti per i lavoratori e per l'intero settore delle due ruote.
La crisi finanziaria di KTM rappresenta un duro colpo per l'industria motociclistica europea, che vede uno dei suoi principali attori in seria difficolt√†.

author: Duke University
title: Protected areas for elephants work best if they are connected
text:
Newswise ‚Äî PRETORIA, SOUTH AFRICA ‚Äì Conservation measures have successfully stopped declines in the African savanna elephant population across southern Africa, but the pattern varies locally, according to a new study.
The evidence suggests that the long-term solution to elephant survival requires not only that areas are protected but that they are also connected to allow populations to stabilize naturally, an international research team says.
Their study, published on January 5th in the peer-reviewed journal Science Advances, collected survey estimates and calculated growth rates for more than 100 elephant populations in southern Africa between 1995 and 2020, accounting for an estimated 70% of the global savanna elephant population.
‚ÄúThis is the most comprehensive analysis of growth rates for any large mammal population in the world,‚Äù said co-author Rob Guldemond, director of the Conservation Ecological Research Unit (CERU) at the University of Pretoria, in South Africa.
Overall, the survey‚Äôs results are positive: There are the same number of elephants now as there were 25 years ago, a rare conservation win at a time when the planet is rapidly losing biodiversity. However, the pattern is not consistent across regions. Some areas, such as south Tanzania, eastern Zambia, and northern Zimbabwe, experienced severe declines due to illegal ivory poaching. In contrast, populations in other regions like north Botswana are booming.
‚ÄúUnchecked growth isn‚Äôt necessarily a good thing, however,‚Äù says study co-author Stuart Pimm, the Doris Duke Professor of Conservation at Duke University in North Carolina. ‚ÄúRapidly increasing populations can outgrow and damage their local environment and prove hard to manage ‚Äî introducing a threat to their long-term stability,‚Äù Pimm says.
In addition to documenting local growth rates, the team also looked at the features of the local populations to identify what makes them stable, that is neither growing nor declining.
Elephant populations in well-protected but isolated parks, sometimes called ‚Äúfortress conservation,‚Äù grow rapidly in the absence of threats but are unsustainable in the long term. These elephants will likely need future conservation interventions, such as translocation or birth control, which are both costly and intensive endeavors.
The team found that the most stable populations occur in large, core areas that are surrounded by buffer zones. The core areas are defined by their strong levels of environmental protection and minimal human impact, whereas the buffers allow some activities such as sustainable farming, forestry, or trophy hunting. Unlike the insular fortresses, core areas are connected to other parks, allowing herds to move naturally.
‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs crucial is that you need a mix of areas with more stable core populations linked to more variable buffer areas,‚Äù said lead author Ryan Huang, a Duke Ph.D. now doing postdoctoral research at CERU.
‚ÄúThese buffers absorb immigrants when core populations get too high, but also provide escape routes when elephants face poor environmental conditions or other threats such as poaching,‚Äù Huang said.
Connecting protected areas means elephants can freely move in and out. This allows a natural equilibrium to occur without human intervention, sparing conservationists from using their limited resources to maintain balance.
‚ÄúCalling for connecting parks isn‚Äôt something new. Many have done so,‚Äù Huang said. ‚ÄúBut surprisingly, there has not been a lot of published evidence of its effectiveness so far. This study helps quantify why this works.‚Äù
‚ÄúConnecting protected areas is essential for the survival of African savanna elephants and many other animal and plant species,‚Äù said Celest√© Mar√©, co-author and doctoral student at Aarhus University in Denmark. ‚ÄúPopulations with more options for moving around are healthier and more stable, which is important given an uncertain future from climate change.‚Äù
